data.title: Multilevel Monte Carlo methods
data.text:
1. Introduction

1.1. Stochastic modelling and Monte Carlo simulation

Stochastic modelling and simulation is a growing area in applied mathematics and scientific computing. One large application area is in computational finance, in the pricing of financial derivatives and quantitative risk management (Glasserman Reference Glasserman2004, Asmussen and Glynn Reference Asmussen and Glynn2007). Another is uncertainty quantification in engineering and science, which has led to a new SIAM journal and associated annual conferences. Stochastic modelling is also important in diverse areas such as biochemical reactions (Anderson and Higham Reference Anderson and Higham2012) and plasma physics (Rosin et al. Reference Rosin, Ricketson, Dimits, Caflisch and Cohen2014).

When the dimensionality of the uncertainty (or the number of uncertain input parameters) is low, it can be appropriate to model the uncertainty using the FokkerPlanck PDE and use stochastic Galerkin, stochastic collocation or polynomial chaos methods (Xiu and Karniadakis Reference Xiu and Karniadakis2002, Babuka, Tempone and Zouraris Reference Babuka, Tempone and Zouraris2004, Babuka, Nobile and Tempone Reference Babuka, Nobile and Tempone2010, Gunzburger, Webster and Zhang Reference Gunzburger, Webster and Zhang2014). When the level of uncertainty is low, and its effect is largely linear, then moment methods can be an efficient and accurate way in which to quantify the effects on uncertainty (Putko, Taylor, Newman and Green Reference Putko, Taylor, Newman and Green2002). However, when the uncertainty is high-dimensional and strongly nonlinear, Monte Carlo simulation remains the preferred approach.

At its simplest, Monte Carlo simulation is extremely simple. To estimate $\mathbb{E}[P]$ , a simple Monte Carlo estimate is just an average of values $P({\it\omega})$ for $N$ independent samples ${\it\omega}$ coming from a given probability space $({\rm\Omega},{\mathcal{F}},\mathbb{P})$ ,

$$\begin{eqnarray}N^{-1}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N}P({\it\omega}^{(n)}).\end{eqnarray}$$

The variance of this estimate is $N^{-1}\,\mathbb{V}[P]$ , so the root mean square (RMS) error is $O(N^{-1/2})$ and an accuracy of ${\it\varepsilon}$ requires $N=O({\it\varepsilon}^{-2})$ samples. This is the weakness of Monte Carlo simulation: its computational cost can be very high, particularly when each sample $P({\it\omega})$ might require the approximate solution of a PDE, or a computation with many time-steps.

One approach to addressing this high cost is the use of quasi-Monte Carlo (QMC) methods, in which the samples are not chosen randomly and independently, but are instead selected very carefully to reduce the error. In the best cases, the error may be $O(N^{-1})$ , up to logarithmic terms, giving a very substantial reduction in the number of samples required for a given accuracy. The QMC approach was surveyed in Acta Numerica 2013 (Dick, Kuo and Sloan Reference Dick, Kuo and Sloan2013). In this article, we cover a different approach to improving the computational efficiency, the multilevel Monte Carlo (MLMC) method, and we include a brief discussion of the combination of the two approaches.

1.2. Control variates and two-level MLMC

One of the classic approaches to Monte Carlo variance reduction is through the use of a control variate (Glasserman Reference Glasserman2004). Suppose we wish to estimate $\mathbb{E}[f]$ , and there is a control variate $g$ which is well correlated to $f$ and has a known expectation $\mathbb{E}[g]$ . In that case, we can use the following unbiased estimator for $\mathbb{E}[f]$ based on $N$ independent samples ${\it\omega}^{(n)}$ :

$$\begin{eqnarray}N^{-1}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N}\big\{f({\it\omega}^{(n)})-{\it\lambda}(g({\it\omega}^{(n)})-\mathbb{E}[g])\big\}.\end{eqnarray}$$

The optimal value for ${\it\lambda}$ is ${\it\rho}\sqrt{\mathbb{V}[f]\,/\,\mathbb{V}[g]}$ , where ${\it\rho}$ is the correlation between $f$ and $g$ , and the variance of the control variate estimator is reduced by factor $1-{\it\rho}^{2}$ compared to the standard estimator.

A two-level version of MLMC is very similar. If we want to estimate $\mathbb{E}[P_{1}]$ but it is much cheaper to simulate $P_{0}$ which approximates $P_{1}$ , then since

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[P_{1}]=\mathbb{E}[P_{0}]+\mathbb{E}[P_{1}-P_{0}]\end{eqnarray}$$

we can use the unbiased two-level estimator

$$\begin{eqnarray}N_{0}^{-1}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N_{0}}P_{0}^{(n)}+N_{1}^{-1}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N_{1}}(P_{1}^{(n)}-P_{0}^{(n)}).\end{eqnarray}$$

Here $P_{1}^{(n)}-P_{0}^{(n)}$ represents the difference between $P_{1}$ and $P_{0}$ for the same underlying stochastic sample ${\it\omega}^{(n)}$ , so that $P_{1}^{(n)}-P_{0}^{(n)}$ is small and has a small variance; the precise construction depends on the application, and various examples will be shown later. The two key differences from the control variate approach are that the value of $\mathbb{E}[P_{0}]$ is not known, so has to be estimated, and we use ${\it\lambda}=1$ .

If we define $C_{0}$ and $C_{1}$ to be the cost of computing a single sample of $P_{0}$ and $P_{1}-P_{0}$ , respectively, then the total cost is $N_{0}\,C_{0}+N_{1}\,C_{1},$ and if $V_{0}$ and $V_{1}$ are the variance of $P_{0}$ and $P_{1}-P_{0}$ , then the overall variance is $N_{0}^{-1}V_{0}+N_{1}^{-1}V_{1},$ assuming that $\sum _{n=1}^{N_{0}}P_{0}^{(n)}$ and $\sum _{n=1}^{N_{1}}(P_{1}^{(n)}-P_{0}^{(n)})$ use independent samples.

Hence, treating the integers $N_{0},N_{1}$ as real variables and performing a constrained minimization using a Lagrange multiplier, the variance is minimized for a fixed cost by choosing $N_{1}/\,N_{0}=\sqrt{V_{1}/C_{1}}~/\sqrt{V_{0}/C_{0}}.$

1.3. Multilevel Monte Carlo

The multilevel generalization is quite natural: given a sequence $P_{0},\ldots ,P_{L-1}$ which approximates $P_{L}$ with increasing accuracy, but also increasing cost, we have the simple identity

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[P_{L}]=\mathbb{E}[P_{0}]+\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =1}^{L}\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}],\end{eqnarray}$$

and therefore we can use the following unbiased estimator for $\mathbb{E}[P_{L}]$ :

$$\begin{eqnarray}N_{0}^{-1}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N_{0}}P_{0}^{(0,n)}+\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =1}^{L}\bigg\{N_{\ell }^{-1}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N_{\ell }}(P_{\ell }^{(\ell ,n)}-P_{\ell -1}^{(\ell ,n)})\bigg\}\end{eqnarray}$$

where the inclusion of the level $\ell$ in the superscript $(\ell ,n)$ indicates that independent samples are used at each level of correction.

If we define $C_{0},V_{0}$ to be the cost and variance of one sample of $P_{0}$ , and $C_{\ell },V_{\ell }$ to be the cost and variance of one sample of $P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}$ , then the overall cost and variance of the multilevel estimator are $\sum _{\ell =0}^{L}N_{\ell }\,C_{\ell }$ and $\sum _{\ell =0}^{L}N_{\ell }^{-1}\,V_{\ell }$ , respectively.

For a fixed cost, the variance is minimized by choosing $N_{\ell }$ to minimize

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}(N_{\ell }^{-1}\,V_{\ell }+{\it\mu}^{2}N_{\ell }\,C_{\ell })\end{eqnarray}$$

for some value of the Lagrange multiplier ${\it\mu}^{2}$ . This gives $N_{\ell }={\it\mu}\sqrt{V_{\ell }\,/\,C_{\ell }}.$ To achieve an overall variance of ${\it\varepsilon}^{2}$ then requires that

$$\begin{eqnarray}{\it\mu}={\it\varepsilon}^{-2}~\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}\sqrt{V_{\ell }~C_{\ell }},\end{eqnarray}$$

and the total computational cost is therefore

(1.1) $$\begin{eqnarray}C={\it\varepsilon}^{-2}\biggl(\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}\sqrt{V_{\ell }~C_{\ell }}\biggr)^{2}.\end{eqnarray}$$

It is important to note whether the product $V_{\ell }~C_{\ell }$ increases or decreases with $\ell$ , that is, whether or not the cost increases with level faster than the variance decreases. If the product increases with level, so that the dominant contribution to the cost comes from $V_{L}\,C_{L}$ , then we have $C\approx {\it\varepsilon}^{-2}V_{L}\,C_{L}$ , whereas if it decreases and the dominant contribution comes from $V_{0}\,C_{0}$ , then $C\approx {\it\varepsilon}^{-2}V_{0}\,C_{0}$ . This contrasts with the standard MC cost of approximately ${\it\varepsilon}^{-2}V_{0}\,C_{L}$ , assuming that the cost of computing $P_{L}$ is similar to the cost of computing $P_{L}-P_{L-1}$ , and that $\mathbb{V}[P_{L}]\approx \mathbb{V}[P_{0}]$ .

This shows that in the first case the MLMC cost is reduced by factor $V_{L}/V_{0}$ , corresponding to the ratio of the variances $\mathbb{V}[P_{L}-P_{L-1}]$ and $\mathbb{V}[P_{L}]$ , whereas in the second case it is reduced by factor $C_{0}/C_{L}$ , the ratio of the costs of computing $P_{0}$ and $P_{L}-P_{L-1}$ . If the product $V_{\ell }~C_{\ell }$ does not vary with level, then the total cost is ${\it\varepsilon}^{-2}L^{2}\,V_{0}\,C_{0}={\it\varepsilon}^{-2}L^{2}\,V_{L}\,C_{L}$ .

1.4. Origins of MLMC method

The first work on multilevel Monte Carlo methods was by Heinrich for parametric integration, the evaluation of functionals arising from the solution of integral equations, and weakly singular integral operators (Heinrich Reference Heinrich1998, Heinrich and Sindambiwe Reference Heinrich and Sindambiwe1999, Heinrich Reference Heinrich, Balakrishnan, Melas and Ermakov2000, Heinrich Reference Heinrich2001, Heinrich Reference Heinrich2006). Parametric integration concerns the estimation of $\mathbb{E}[f(x,{\it\lambda})]$ , where $x$ is a finite-dimensional random variable and ${\it\lambda}$ is a parameter. In the simplest case in which ${\it\lambda}$ is a scalar real variable in the range $[0,1]$ , having estimated the value of $\mathbb{E}[f(x,0)]$ and $\mathbb{E}[f(x,1)]$ , one can use $(f(x,0)+f(x,1))/2$ as a control variate when estimating the value of $\mathbb{E}[f(x,1/2)]$ . Heinrich applied this idea recursively on a geometric sequence of levels, leading to a complexity analysis which is very similar to that which will be outlined later.

Although not so clearly related, there are also papers by Brandt et al. (Brandt, Galun and Ron Reference Brandt, Galun and Ron1994, Brandt and Ilyin Reference Brandt and Ilyin2003) which combine Monte Carlo techniques with multigrid ideas in determining thermodynamic limits in statistical physics applications.

Kebaier (Reference Kebaier2005) developed a two-level approach for path simulation which is very similar to the authors approach (Giles Reference Giles, Keller, Heinrich and Niederreiter2008a , Reference Giles2008b ), which was inspired by the multigrid ideas of Brandt and others for the iterative solution of PDE approximations. The differences are that Kebaier used only two levels, and used a general multiplicative factor as in the standard control variate approach. There was also similar independent work at the same time by Li (Reference Li2007) and Speight (Reference Speight2009).

1.5. Outline of article

Section 2 presents the main theoretical results which underpin MLMC methods, and a number of different generalizations and extensions, many of which have been developed very recently.

Section 3 presents in some detail a MATLAB implementation of MLMC. This is used to generate the numerical results which are presented later, and the full MATLAB code is available online (Giles Reference Giles2014).

Sections 410 cover a wide range of applications, demonstrating the flexibility and generality of the MLMC approach, documenting progress in the numerical analysis of the methods, and illustrating techniques which can be used to improve the variance of the MLMC estimators. Particular attention is paid to the difficulties caused by discontinuities in output functionals, and a variety of remedies which can be employed.

Finally, Section 11 concludes with some thoughts about directions for future research.

Readers who are new to the subject may wish to start with Section 2.1 and then proceed to the application sections most relevant to their interests.

2. MLMC theory and extensions

2.1. Geometric MLMC

In the Introduction, we considered the case of a general multilevel method in which the output $P_{L}$ on the finest level corresponds to the quantity of interest. However, in many infinite-dimensional applications, such as those which involve the simulation of SDEs and SPDEs, the output $P_{\ell }$ on level $\ell$ is an approximation to a random variable $P$ which cannot be simulated exactly. If $Y$ is an approximation to $\mathbb{E}[P]$ , then a standard piece of theory gives the mean square error (MSE) as

(2.1) $$\begin{eqnarray}\text{MSE}\equiv \mathbb{E}[(Y-\mathbb{E}[P])^{2}]=\mathbb{V}[Y]+(\mathbb{E}[Y]-\mathbb{E}[P])^{2}.\end{eqnarray}$$

If $Y$ is now the multilevel estimator

(2.2) $$\begin{eqnarray}Y=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}Y_{\ell },\quad Y_{\ell }=N_{\ell }^{-1}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N_{\ell }}(P_{\ell }^{(\ell ,n)}-P_{\ell -1}^{(\ell ,n)}),\end{eqnarray}$$

with $P_{-1}\equiv 0$ , then

(2.3) $$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[Y]=\mathbb{E}[P_{L}],\quad \mathbb{V}[Y]=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}N_{\ell }^{-1}V_{\ell },\quad V_{\ell }\equiv \mathbb{V}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}].\end{eqnarray}$$

To ensure that the MSE is less than ${\it\varepsilon}^{2}$ , it is sufficient to ensure that $\mathbb{V}[Y]$ and $(\mathbb{E}[P_{L}-P])^{2}$ are both less than ${\it\varepsilon}^{2}/2$ . Combining this idea with a geometric sequence of levels in which the cost increases exponentially with level, while both the weak error $\mathbb{E}[P_{L}-P]$ and the multilevel correction variance $V_{\ell }$ decrease exponentially, leads to the following theorem.

Theorem 2.1. Let $P$ denote a random variable, and let $P_{\ell }$ denote the corresponding level $\ell$ numerical approximation.

If there exist independent estimators $Y_{\ell }$ based on $N_{\ell }$ Monte Carlo samples, each with expected cost $C_{\ell }$ and variance $V_{\ell }$ , and positive constants ${\it\alpha},{\it\beta},{\it\gamma},c_{1},c_{2},c_{3}$ such that ${\it\alpha}\geq {\textstyle \frac{1}{2}}\min ({\it\beta},{\it\gamma})$ and

(i) $|\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P]|\leq c_{1}\,2^{-{\it\alpha}\,\ell },$

(ii) $\mathbb{E}[Y_{\ell }]=\left\{\begin{array}{@{}ll@{}}\mathbb{E}[P_{0}]\quad & \ell =0,\\ \mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]\quad & \ell >0,\end{array}\right.$

(iii) $V_{\ell }\leq c_{2}\,2^{-{\it\beta}\,\ell },$

(iv) $C_{\ell }\leq c_{3}\,2^{{\it\gamma}\,\ell },$

then there exists a positive constant $c_{4}$ such that for any ${\it\varepsilon}<e^{-1}$ there are values $L$ and $N_{\ell }$ for which the multilevel estimator

$$\begin{eqnarray}Y=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}Y_{\ell }\end{eqnarray}$$

has a mean square error with bound

$$\begin{eqnarray}\text{MSE}\equiv \mathbb{E}[(Y-\mathbb{E}[P])^{2}]<{\it\varepsilon}^{2}\end{eqnarray}$$

with a computational complexity $C$ with bound

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[C]\leq \left\{\begin{array}{@{}ll@{}}c_{4}\,{\it\varepsilon}^{-2}\quad & {\it\beta}>{\it\gamma},\\ c_{4}\,{\it\varepsilon}^{-2}(\log {\it\varepsilon})^{2}\quad & {\it\beta}={\it\gamma},\\ c_{4}\,{\it\varepsilon}^{-2-({\it\gamma}-{\it\beta})/{\it\alpha}}\quad & {\it\beta}<{\it\gamma}.\end{array}\right.\end{eqnarray}$$

The statement of the theorem is a slight generalization of the original theorem in Giles (Reference Giles2008b ). It corresponds to the theorem and proof in Cliffe, Giles, Scheichl and Teckentrup (Reference Cliffe, Giles, Scheichl and Teckentrup2011), except for the minor change to expected costs to allow for applications in which the simulation cost of individual samples is itself random. Note that if condition (iii) is tightened slightly to be a bound on $\mathbb{E}[(P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1})^{2}]$ , which is usually the quantity which is bounded in numerical analysis, then it would follow immediately that ${\it\alpha}\geq {\it\beta}/2$ .

The essence of the proof is very straightforward. If we have $V_{\ell }=O(2^{-{\it\beta}\ell })$ and $C_{\ell }=O(2^{{\it\gamma}\ell })$ , then the analysis in Section 1.3 shows that the optimal number of samples $N_{\ell }$ on level $\ell$ is proportional to $2^{-({\it\beta}+{\it\gamma})\ell /2}$ , and therefore the cost on level $\ell$ is proportional to $2^{({\it\gamma}-{\it\beta})\ell /2}$ . The result then follows from the requirement that $L$ is chosen so that $(\mathbb{E}[Y]-\mathbb{E}[P])^{2}<{\it\varepsilon}^{2}/2$ , and the constant of proportionality for $N_{\ell }$ is chosen so that $\mathbb{V}[Y]<{\it\varepsilon}^{2}/2$ . The proof also has to handle the fact that $N_{\ell }$ must be an integer, so the optimal value is rounded up to the nearest integer.

The result of the theorem merits some discussion. In the case ${\it\beta}>{\it\gamma}$ , the dominant computational cost is on the coarsest levels where $C_{\ell }=O(1)$ and $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-2})$ samples are required to achieve the desired accuracy. This is the standard result for a Monte Carlo approach using i.i.d. samples; to do better would require an alternative approach such as the use of Latin hypercube sampling or quasi-Monte Carlo methods.

In the case ${\it\beta}<{\it\gamma}$ , the dominant computational cost is on the finest levels. Because of condition (i), we have $2^{-{\it\alpha}L}=O({\it\varepsilon})$ , and hence $C_{L}=O({\it\varepsilon}^{-{\it\gamma}/{\it\alpha}})$ . If ${\it\beta}=2{\it\alpha}$ , which is usually the best that can be achieved since typically $\mathbb{V}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]$ is similar in magnitude to $\mathbb{E}[(P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1})^{2}]$ , which is greater than $(\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}])^{2}$ , then the total cost is $O(C_{L})$ , corresponding to $O(1)$ samples on the finest level, which is the best that can be achieved.

The dividing case ${\it\beta}={\it\gamma}$ is the one for which both the computational effort, and the contributions to the overall variance, are spread approximately evenly across all of the levels; the $(\log {\it\varepsilon})^{2}$ term corresponds to the $L^{2}$ factor in the corresponding discussion at the end of Section 1.3.

One comment on the theorem is that it assumes lots of properties, and then from these determines relatively easily some conclusions for the efficiency of the MLMC approach. In real applications, the tough challenge is in proving that the assumptions are valid, and in particular determining the values of the parameters ${\it\alpha},{\it\beta},{\it\gamma}$ . Furthermore, the theorem assumes knowledge of the constants $c_{1},c_{2},c_{3}$ . In practice, $c_{1}$ and $c_{2}$ are almost never known, and instead have to be estimated based on empirical estimates of the weak error and the multilevel correction variance.

Collier et al. (Reference Collier, Haji-Ali, Nobile, von Schwerin and Tempone2014) have developed a modified version of the theorem. Instead of bounding the mean square error, they prefer to use the Central Limit Theorem to construct a confidence interval which bounds $\mathbb{E}[P]$ with a user-prescribed confidence. This exploits the fact that the multilevel correction $Y_{\ell }$ on each level is asymptotically normally distributed, and therefore so is $Y$ .

Haji-Ali, Nobile, von Schwerin and Tempone (Reference Haji-Ali, Nobile, von Schwerin and Tempone2014b ) address two other important points. The first is whether a geometric sequence of levels is the best choice. Their analysis proves that under certain conditions there is negligible benefit in using a non-geometric sequence, but later in Section 2.6 we will discuss other applications in which a non-geometric sequence is appropriate. The second point is that the equal split between the error due to $\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]$ and the error due to the variance $\mathbb{V}[Y]$ is definitely not optimal. When ${\it\beta}>{\it\gamma}$ , the dominant computational effort is on the coarsest levels; therefore $L$ can be increased significantly with negligible cost, and so it makes sense to allocate most of the error to the variance term, which means that fewer samples will be required. This can give up to a factor $2\times$ improvement in computational cost compared to the equal split used in Giles (Reference Giles, Keller, Heinrich and Niederreiter2008a , Reference Giles2008b ).

Equation (2.2) gives the natural choice for the multilevel correction estimator $Y_{\ell }$ . However, the multilevel theorem allows for the use of other estimators, provided they satisfy the restriction of condition (ii), which ensures that $\mathbb{E}[Y]=\mathbb{E}[P_{L}]$ . Several examples of this will be given later in this article. Some use slightly different numerical approximations for the coarse and fine paths in SDE simulations, resulting in the estimator

$$\begin{eqnarray}Y_{\ell }=N_{\ell }^{-1}~\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N_{\ell }}~(P_{\ell }^{f}({\it\omega}^{(n)})-P_{\ell -1}^{c}({\it\omega}^{(n)})).\end{eqnarray}$$

Provided we maintain the identity

(2.4) $$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }^{f}]=\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }^{c}]\end{eqnarray}$$

so that the expectation on level $\ell$ is the same for the two approximations, then condition (ii) is satisfied and no additional bias (other than the bias due to the approximation on the finest level) is introduced into the multilevel estimator.

Some others define an antithetic ${\it\omega}_{a}^{(n)}$ with the same distribution as ${\it\omega}^{(n)}$ , and then use the multilevel estimator

$$\begin{eqnarray}Y_{\ell }=N_{\ell }^{-1}~\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N_{\ell }}~{\textstyle \frac{1}{2}}(P_{\ell }({\it\omega}^{(n)})+P_{\ell }({\it\omega}_{a}^{(n)}))-P_{\ell -1}({\it\omega}^{(n)}).\end{eqnarray}$$

Since $\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }({\it\omega}_{a}^{(n)})]=\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }({\it\omega}^{(n)})]$ , then again condition (ii) is satisfied.

In each case, the objective in constructing a more complex estimator is to achieve a greatly reduced variance $\mathbb{V}[Y_{\ell }]$ so that fewer samples are required.

2.2. Randomized MLMC for unbiased estimation

A very interesting extension has been introduced in Rhee and Glynn (Reference Rhee and Glynn2012, Reference Rhee and Glynn2015). Rather than choosing the finest level of simulation $L$ , based on the desired accuracy, and then using the optimal number of samples on each level based on an estimate of the variance, their single-term estimator instead uses $N$ samples in total, and for each sample they perform a simulation on level $\ell$ with probability $p_{\ell }$ .

The estimator is

$$\begin{eqnarray}Y=\frac{1}{N}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N}\frac{1}{p_{\ell ^{(n)}}}(P_{\ell ^{(n)}}^{(n)}-P_{\ell ^{(n)}-1}^{(n)})\end{eqnarray}$$

with the level $\ell ^{(n)}$ for each sample being selected randomly with the relevant probability. Alternatively, their estimator can be expressed as

$$\begin{eqnarray}Y=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }\biggl(\frac{1}{p_{\ell }\,N}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N_{\ell }}(P_{\ell }^{(n)}-P_{\ell -1}^{(n)})\biggr),\end{eqnarray}$$

where $N_{\ell }$ , the number of samples from level $\ell$ , is a random variable with

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }N_{\ell }=N,\quad \mathbb{E}[N_{\ell }]=p_{\ell }N,\end{eqnarray}$$

and both outer summations can be trivially truncated at the (random) level $L$ beyond which $N_{\ell }=0$ . Note that in this form it is very similar in appearance to the standard MLMC estimator, which is

$$\begin{eqnarray}Y=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}\biggl(\frac{1}{N_{\ell }}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N_{\ell }}(P_{\ell }^{(n)}-P_{\ell -1}^{(n)})\biggr).\end{eqnarray}$$

The beauty of their estimator is that it is naturally unbiased, since

$$\begin{eqnarray}\displaystyle \mathbb{E}[Y] & = & \displaystyle \mathbb{E}\biggl[\frac{1}{p_{\ell ^{\prime }}}(P_{\ell ^{\prime }}-P_{\ell ^{\prime }-1})\biggr]\nonumber\\ \displaystyle & = & \displaystyle \mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }p_{\ell }~\mathbb{E}\biggl[\frac{1}{p_{\ell ^{\prime }}}(P_{\ell ^{\prime }}-P_{\ell ^{\prime }-1})\mid \ell ^{\prime }=\ell \biggr]\nonumber\\ \displaystyle & = & \displaystyle \mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]\nonumber\\ \displaystyle & = & \displaystyle \mathbb{E}[P].\nonumber\end{eqnarray}$$

If we define $E_{\ell }=\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]$ then the variance of the estimator is

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{V}[Y]=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }\frac{1}{p_{\ell }}(V_{\ell }+E_{\ell }^{2})-\biggl(\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }E_{\ell }\biggr)^{2}\geq \mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }\frac{1}{p_{\ell }}\,V_{\ell },\end{eqnarray}$$

due to Jensens inequality.

The choice of probabilities $p_{\ell }$ is crucial. For both the variance and the expected cost to be finite, it is necessary that

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }\frac{1}{p_{\ell }}\,V_{\ell }<\infty ,\quad \mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }p_{\ell }\,C_{\ell }<\infty .\end{eqnarray}$$

Under the conditions of the MLMC theorem, this is possible when ${\it\beta}>{\it\gamma}$ by choosing $p_{\ell }\propto 2^{-({\it\gamma}+{\it\beta})\ell /2},$ so that

$$\begin{eqnarray}\frac{1}{p_{\ell }}\,V_{\ell }\propto 2^{-({\it\beta}-{\it\gamma})\ell /2},\quad p_{\ell }\,C_{\ell }\propto 2^{-({\it\beta}-{\it\gamma})\ell /2}.\end{eqnarray}$$

It is not possible when ${\it\beta}\leq {\it\gamma}$ , and for these cases the estimators constructed by Rhee and Glynn (Reference Rhee and Glynn2015) have infinite expected cost.

Provided ${\it\beta}>{\it\gamma}$ , the optimal choice for $p_{\ell }$ is

$$\begin{eqnarray}p_{\ell }=\sqrt{V_{\ell }/C_{\ell }}~\biggl(\mathop{\sum }_{\ell ^{\prime }=0}^{\infty }\sqrt{V_{\ell ^{\prime }}/C_{\ell ^{\prime }}}\biggr)^{-1}.\end{eqnarray}$$

If $E_{\ell }^{2}\ll V_{\ell }$ , then the condition that the variance of the estimator is approximately equal to ${\it\varepsilon}^{2}$ gives

$$\begin{eqnarray}N\approx {\it\varepsilon}^{-2}\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }V_{\ell }/p_{\ell }\approx {\it\varepsilon}^{-2}\biggl(\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }\sqrt{V_{\ell }\,C_{\ell }}\biggr)\biggl(\mathop{\sum }_{\ell ^{\prime }=0}^{\infty }\sqrt{V_{\ell ^{\prime }}/C_{\ell ^{\prime }}}\biggr)\end{eqnarray}$$

and therefore the total cost is

$$\begin{eqnarray}C=N\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }p_{\ell }\,C_{\ell }\approx {\it\varepsilon}^{-2}\biggl(\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{\infty }\sqrt{V_{\ell }\,C_{\ell }}\biggr)^{2},\end{eqnarray}$$

which is the same as the total cost in equation (1.1), and half the cost of the standard MLMC algorithm in which only half of the MSE budget of ${\it\varepsilon}^{2}$ is allocated to the variance.

Although it is very elegant to have an unbiased estimator when ${\it\beta}>{\it\gamma}$ , the practical benefits may be limited. In this situation, the dominant cost of the standard MLMC algorithm is on the coarsest levels of simulation, and therefore one can increase the value of $L$ substantially at negligible cost, and at the same time allocate almost all of the MSE budget of ${\it\varepsilon}^{2}$ to the variance term in (2.1), leading to approximately the same total cost.

2.3. Multilevel RichardsonRomberg extrapolation

Richardson extrapolation is a very old technique in numerical analysis. Given a numerical approximation $P_{h}$ based on a discretization parameter $h$ which leads to an error

$$\begin{eqnarray}P_{h}-P=a\,h^{{\it\alpha}}+O(h^{2{\it\alpha}}),\end{eqnarray}$$

it follows that

$$\begin{eqnarray}P_{2h}-P=a\,(2h)^{{\it\alpha}}+O(h^{2{\it\alpha}}),\end{eqnarray}$$

and hence the extrapolated value

$$\begin{eqnarray}\widetilde{P}=\frac{2^{{\it\alpha}}}{2^{{\it\alpha}}-1}\,P_{h}-\frac{1}{2^{{\it\alpha}}-1}\,P_{2h}\end{eqnarray}$$

satisfies

$$\begin{eqnarray}\widetilde{P}-P=O(h^{2{\it\alpha}}).\end{eqnarray}$$

At the suggestion of a reviewer, the authors original MLMC paper (Giles Reference Giles2008b ) included results using one level of Richardson extrapolation, both for the multilevel results as well as the standard Monte Carlo method. Multilevel on its own was significantly better than Richardson extrapolation, but the two together were even better.

Lemaire and Pags have taken this approach much further, and have also performed a comprehensive error analysis (Lemaire and Pags Reference Lemaire and Pags2013). Assuming that the weak error has a regular expansion

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }]-\mathbb{E}[P]=\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{L}a_{n}2^{-n{\it\alpha}\ell }+O(2^{-{\it\alpha}\ell L}),\end{eqnarray}$$

they first determine the unique set of weights $w_{\ell },\,\ell =0,1,\ldots ,L$ such that

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}w_{\ell }=1,\quad \mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}w_{\ell }\,2^{-n{\it\alpha}\ell }=1,\quad n=1,\ldots ,L,\end{eqnarray}$$

so that

$$\begin{eqnarray}\biggl(\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}w_{\ell }\,\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }]\biggr)-\mathbb{E}[P]=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}w_{\ell }\,(\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }]-\mathbb{E}[P])=O(2^{-{\it\alpha}L^{2}}).\end{eqnarray}$$

Next, they rearrange terms to give

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}w_{\ell }\,\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }]=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}v_{\ell }\,\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}],\end{eqnarray}$$

where as usual $P_{-1}\equiv 0$ , and the coefficients $v_{\ell }$ are defined by $w_{\ell }=v_{\ell }-v_{\ell +1}$ , with $v_{L+1}\equiv 0$ , and hence

$$\begin{eqnarray}v_{\ell }=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell ^{\prime }=\ell }^{L}w_{\ell ^{\prime }}.\end{eqnarray}$$

This leads to their multilevel RichardsonRomberg extrapolation estimator,

$$\begin{eqnarray}Y=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}Y_{\ell },\quad Y_{\ell }=N_{\ell }^{-1}v_{\ell }\mathop{\sum }_{n}(P_{\ell }^{(\ell ,n)}-P_{\ell -1}^{(\ell ,n)}).\end{eqnarray}$$

Because the remaining error is $O(2^{-{\it\alpha}L^{2}})$ , rather than the usual $O(2^{-{\it\alpha}L})$ , it is possible to obtain the usual $O({\it\varepsilon})$ weak error with a value of $L$ which is the square root of the usual value. Hence, in the case ${\it\beta}={\it\gamma}$ they prove that the overall cost is reduced to $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-2}|\log \,{\it\varepsilon}|)$ , while for ${\it\beta}<{\it\gamma}$ the cost is reduced much more to $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-2}2^{({\it\gamma}-{\it\beta})\sqrt{}(|\log _{2}{\it\varepsilon}|/{\it\alpha})})$ . This analysis is supported by numerical results which demonstrate considerable savings (Lemaire and Pags Reference Lemaire and Pags2013), and therefore this appears to be a very useful extension to the standard MLMC approach when ${\it\beta}\leq {\it\gamma}$ .

2.4. Multi-index Monte Carlo

Multi-index Monte Carlo (MIMC) is probably the most significant extension of the MLMC methodology (Haji-Ali, Nobile and Tempone Reference Haji-Ali, Nobile and Tempone2014a ). In standard MLMC, there is a one-dimensional set of levels, with a scalar level index $\ell$ , although in some applications changing $\ell$ can change more than one aspect of the computation (such as both time-step and spatial discretization in a parabolic SPDE application, or time-step and number of sub-samples in a nested simulation). MIMC generalizes this to levels being defined in multiple directions, so that the level index $\boldsymbol{\ell }$ is now a vector of integer indices. This is illustrated in Figure 2.1 for a two-dimensional MIMC application.

In MLMC, if we define the backward difference

$$\begin{eqnarray}{\rm\Delta}P_{\ell }\equiv P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}\end{eqnarray}$$

with $P_{-1}\equiv 0$ , as usual, then the telescoping sum which lies at the heart of MLMC is

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[P]=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell \geq 0}\mathbb{E}[{\rm\Delta}P_{\ell }].\end{eqnarray}$$

Generalizing this to $D$ dimensions, Haji-Ali et al. (Reference Haji-Ali, Nobile and Tempone2014a ) first define a backward difference operator in one particular dimension,

$$\begin{eqnarray}{\rm\Delta}_{d}P_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}\equiv P_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}-P_{\boldsymbol{\ell }-\boldsymbol{e}_{d}},\end{eqnarray}$$

where $\boldsymbol{e}_{d}$ is the unit vector in direction $d$ . They then define the cross-difference

$$\begin{eqnarray}{\bf\Delta}P_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}\equiv \biggl(\mathop{\prod }_{d=1}^{D}{\rm\Delta}_{d}\biggr)P_{\boldsymbol{\ell }},\end{eqnarray}$$

and the telescoping sum becomes

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[P]=\mathop{\sum }_{\boldsymbol{\ell }\geq 0}\mathbb{E}[{\bf\Delta}P_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}].\end{eqnarray}$$

As an example, Figure 2.1 marks the four locations at which $P_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}$ must be computed to determine the value of ${\bf\Delta}P_{(5,4)}$ in the two-dimensional application.

The MIMC theorem formulated by Haji-Ali et al. (Reference Haji-Ali, Nobile and Tempone2014a ) can be expressed in the following form to match, as closely as possible, the formulation of the MLMC theorem.

Theorem 2.2. If there exist independent estimators $Y_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}$ based on $N_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}$ Monte Carlo samples, each with expected cost $C_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}$ and variance $V_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}$ , and positive $D$ -dimensional vectors ${\bf\alpha},{\bf\beta},{\bf\gamma}$ , with ${\it\alpha}_{d}\geq {\it\beta}_{d}/2$ , and also positive constants $c_{1},c_{2},c_{3}$ such that

(i) $|\mathbb{E}[P_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}-P]|\longrightarrow 0\text{ as }\min _{d}\ell _{d}\longrightarrow \infty ,$

(ii) $\mathbb{E}[Y_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}]=\mathbb{E}[{\bf\Delta}P_{\ell }],$

(iii) $|\mathbb{E}[Y_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}]|\leq c_{1}\,2^{-{\bf\alpha}\cdot \boldsymbol{\ell }},$

(iv) $V_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}\leq c_{2}\,2^{-{\bf\beta}\cdot \boldsymbol{\ell }},$

(v) $C_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}\leq c_{3}\,2^{{\bf\gamma}\cdot \boldsymbol{\ell }},$

then there exists a positive constant $c_{4}$ such that for any ${\it\varepsilon}<e^{-1}$ there is a set of levels ${\mathcal{L}}$ , and integers $N_{\ell }$ for which the multilevel estimator

$$\begin{eqnarray}Y=\mathop{\sum }_{\boldsymbol{\ell }\in {\mathcal{L}}}Y_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}\end{eqnarray}$$

has a mean square error with bound

$$\begin{eqnarray}\text{MSE}\equiv \mathbb{E}[(Y-\mathbb{E}[P])^{2}]<{\it\varepsilon}^{2},\end{eqnarray}$$

with a computational complexity $C$ with bound

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[C]\leq \left\{\begin{array}{@{}ll@{}}c_{4}\,{\it\varepsilon}^{-2}\quad & {\it\eta}<0,\\ c_{4}\,{\it\varepsilon}^{-2}\,|\log \,{\it\varepsilon}|^{e_{1}}\quad & {\it\eta}=0,\\ c_{4}\,{\it\varepsilon}^{-2-{\it\eta}}\,|\log \,{\it\varepsilon}|^{e_{2}}\quad & {\it\eta}>0,\end{array}\right.\end{eqnarray}$$

where

$$\begin{eqnarray}{\it\eta}=\max _{d}\frac{{\it\gamma}_{d}-{\it\beta}_{d}}{{\it\alpha}_{d}}.\end{eqnarray}$$

When ${\it\alpha}_{d}>{\it\beta}_{d}/2$ for all $d$ , the exponents for the logarithmic terms are

$$\begin{eqnarray}e_{1}=2\,D_{2},\quad e_{2}=(D_{2}-1)\,(2+{\it\eta}),\end{eqnarray}$$

where $D_{2}$ is the number of dimensions $d$ for which

$$\begin{eqnarray}\frac{{\it\gamma}_{d}-{\it\beta}_{d}}{{\it\alpha}_{d}}={\it\eta}.\end{eqnarray}$$

The form of the exponents is more complicated when ${\it\alpha}_{d}={\it\beta}_{d}/2$ for some $d$ (Haji-Ali et al. Reference Haji-Ali, Nobile and Tempone2014a ).

Notes.

 Condition (i) ensures weak convergence to the correct value.

 Condition (ii) ensures each $Y_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}$ has the correct expected value. This allows for the possibility of using an estimator which is more complicated than the natural choice $Y_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}={\bf\Delta}P_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}$ , if it will lead to a reduced variance.

 Conditions (iii) and (iv) give the order of convergence of the weak error and the multilevel correction variance, and condition (v) gives the rate at which the cost increases with level.

 The proof of the theorem is significantly harder than for the MLMC theorem.

 There is again the difficulty for each new application of determining ${\bf\alpha},{\bf\beta},{\bf\gamma}$ for conditions (iii)(v). A relatively simple example will be given later in Section 9.

It might seem natural that the summation region ${\mathcal{L}}$ should be rectangular, as illustrated in Figure 2.2(a), so that

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathop{\sum }_{\boldsymbol{\ell }\in {\mathcal{L}}}Y_{\boldsymbol{\ell }}=P_{\boldsymbol{L}}\end{eqnarray}$$

where $\boldsymbol{L}$ is the outermost point on the rectangle. However, Haji-Ali et al. (Reference Haji-Ali, Nobile and Tempone2014a ) prove that this gives the optimal order of complexity only when ${\it\eta}<0$ , and under the additional condition that

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathop{\sum }_{d}\frac{{\it\gamma}_{d}}{{\it\alpha}_{d}}\leq 2.\end{eqnarray}$$

The optimal choice for ${\mathcal{L}}$ , which yields the complexity bounds given in the theorem, is of the form $\boldsymbol{\ell }\cdot \mathbf{n}\leq L$ for a particular choice of direction vector $\mathbf{n}$ with strictly positive components. In two dimensions, this corresponds to a triangular region, as illustrated in Figure 2.2(b). This is very similar to the use of sparse grid methods in high-dimensional PDE approximations (Bungartz and Griebel Reference Bungartz and Griebel2004), and indeed MIMC can be viewed as a combination of sparse grid methods and Monte Carlo sampling.

The benefits of MIMC over the standard MLMC can be very substantial. They are perhaps best illustrated by an elliptic PDE or SPDE example, in which $D$ corresponds to the number of spatial dimensions. Using the standard MLMC approach, ${\it\beta}$ , the rate of convergence of the multilevel variance, will usually be independent of $D$ , but ${\it\gamma}$ , the rate of increase in the computational cost, will increase at least linearly with $D$ . Therefore, in a high enough dimension we will have ${\it\beta}\leq {\it\gamma}$ and therefore the overall computational complexity will be less (often much less) than the optimal $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-2})$ . However, using MIMC we can have ${\it\beta}_{d}>{\it\gamma}_{d}$ in each direction, and therefore obtain the optimal complexity.

Hence, in the same way that sparse grids offer the possibility of dimension-independent complexity for deterministic PDE applications, MIMC offers the possibility of dimension-independent complexity for SPDEs and other high-dimensional stochastic applications.

2.5. Multi-dimensional output functionals

In Monte Carlo simulation, we start with a sample ${\it\omega}$ from the random input space, often compute an intermediate solution $U$ from an approximation to an SDE or SPDE, and then determine the final output quantity $P$ .

$$\begin{eqnarray}{\it\omega}\longrightarrow U\longrightarrow P\end{eqnarray}$$

So far, the discussion in this article has focused on the idea of $P$ being a scalar output, but this is not necessarily always the case. In some applications there may be more than one scalar output of interest, and in other applications $P$ may be infinite-dimensional.

Some of the possibilities are listed in Table 2.1. In Heinrichs original multilevel research on parametric integration (Heinrich Reference Heinrich1998, Heinrich and Sindambiwe Reference Heinrich and Sindambiwe1999, Heinrich Reference Heinrich, Balakrishnan, Melas and Ermakov2000, Heinrich Reference Heinrich2001), the sample ${\it\omega}$ was from a finite-dimensional unit hypercube, there was no intermediate solution, and the output was an infinite-dimensional function of a parameter ${\it\lambda}$ . In the authors initial research (Giles Reference Giles, Keller, Heinrich and Niederreiter2008a , Reference Giles2008b ), ${\it\omega}$ represented an infinite-dimensional input Brownian path, $U$ was the solution of an SDE, and $P$ was a scalar functional of that solution $U$ . In the simplest PDE applications, one might have a finite set of parameters which specify uncertain initial or boundary data, and a single scalar output, so only the intermediate PDE solution is infinite-dimensional. Finally, new research (Giles, Nagapetyan and Ritter Reference Giles, Nagapetyan and Ritter2015b ) addresses the problem of approximating the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of exit times associated with the solution of an SDE; in this case, all three spaces are infinite-dimensional.

The extension of the MLMC theory to a finite set of outputs is very natural. The standard MLMC theorem will apply to each one of the outputs. If there is a desired accuracy ${\it\varepsilon}_{m}$ for the $m$ th output, then a simple approach proposed by Tigran NagapetyanFootnote 1 is to define

$$\begin{eqnarray}V_{\ell }\equiv \max _{m}\frac{V_{\ell ,m}}{{\it\varepsilon}_{m}^{2}},\end{eqnarray}$$

where $V_{\ell ,m}$ is the variance of the multilevel estimator on level $\ell$ for the $m$ th output. Enforcing the constraint

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}N_{\ell }^{-1}\,V_{\ell }\leq {\textstyle \frac{1}{2}}\end{eqnarray}$$

is then sufficient to ensure that all of the individual variance constraints are satisfied, and the standard Lagrange multiplier approach outlined in Section 1.3 can be used to determine the optimal number of samples to use on each level.

The extension of the theory to infinite-dimensional outputs requires the definition of an appropriate norm $\Vert \cdot \Vert$ , and then to a large extent the theory carries over by making the substitutions

$$\begin{eqnarray}\displaystyle |\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }]-\mathbb{E}[P]| & \longrightarrow & \displaystyle \Vert \mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }]-\mathbb{E}[P]\Vert ,\nonumber\\ \displaystyle \mathbb{V}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}] & \longrightarrow & \displaystyle \mathbb{E}[\Vert P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}-\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]\Vert ^{2}].\nonumber\end{eqnarray}$$

One slight complication is that if $a$ and $b$ are two independent scalar random variables with zero mean, then

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[(a+b)^{2}]=\mathbb{E}[a^{2}]+\mathbb{E}[b^{2}].\end{eqnarray}$$

When using the 2-norm, this extends to independent random vectors $\boldsymbol{a}$ and $\boldsymbol{b}$ , each with zero mean, since

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[\Vert \boldsymbol{a}+\boldsymbol{b}\Vert ^{2}]=\mathbb{E}[\Vert \boldsymbol{a}\Vert ^{2}]+\mathbb{E}[\Vert \boldsymbol{b}\Vert ^{2}],\end{eqnarray}$$

and similarly to random functions with a 2-norm based on an inner product. However this does not necessarily apply for other norms, and so the variance for the combined multilevel estimator cannot necessarily be expressed in the usual form as

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathop{\sum }_{\ell }N_{\ell }^{-1}V_{\ell },\quad V_{\ell }\equiv \mathbb{E}[\Vert P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}-\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]\Vert ^{2}].\end{eqnarray}$$

Nevertheless, the theory can be extended to the use of other norms by using results from Banach space theory for the sums of independent random variables (Ledoux and Talagrand Reference Ledoux and Talagrand1991, Heinrich Reference Heinrich1998), and in recent research Daun and Heinrich have addressed the challenges of parametric integration in infinite-dimensional Banach spaces (Daun and Heinrich Reference Daun, Heinrich, Dick, Kuo, Peters and Sloan2013, Reference Daun and Heinrich2014a , Reference Daun and Heinrich2014b ).

2.6. Non-geometric MLMC

It is very important to repeat, and emphasize, the fact that MLMC does not require the use of a geometric sequence of grids. In many applications, and most of the existing literature, a geometric sequence will be the appropriate choice, but there are other applications for which it is not. The only assumptions in the analysis of the two-level method in Section 1.2 and the multilevel method in Section 1.3 are that the accuracy and cost increase with level, and the variance of the correction term decreases with level.

When there is no underlying structure to suggest that a geometric sequence is appropriate, a question which arises is how to select the levels. Suppose that one starts with a large collection of potential levels; how does one decide which subset to use?

One approach developed by Vidal-Codina, Nguyen, Giles and Peraire (Reference Vidal-Codina, Nguyen, Giles and Peraire2014) is to first use a number of trial samples to obtain an estimate of $V_{\ell }=\mathbb{V}[P_{\ell }]$ and $V_{\ell _{1},\ell _{2}}\equiv \mathbb{V}[P_{\ell _{2}}-P_{\ell _{1}}]$ for all pairs $(\ell _{1},\ell _{2})$ , with $\ell _{1}<\ell _{2}$ , with associated costs $C_{\ell }$ and $C_{\ell _{1},\ell _{2}}$ . For a particular ordered subset of levels, $\{\ell _{1},\ell _{2},\ldots ,\ell _{M}\}$ , with fixed $\ell _{M}=L$ to achieve a user-specified accuracy, following the analysis in Section 1.3 which led to (1.1), we obtain the cost

$$\begin{eqnarray}C(\ell _{1},\ell _{2},\ldots ,\ell _{M})={\it\varepsilon}^{-2}\biggl(\sqrt{V_{\ell _{0}}\,C_{\ell _{0}}}+\mathop{\sum }_{m=1}^{M}\sqrt{V_{\ell _{m},\ell _{m-1}}\,C_{\ell _{m},\ell _{m-1}}}\biggr)^{2}.\end{eqnarray}$$

If the maximum number of levels is not too large, it is possible to perform an exhaustive search to find the optimal subset $\{\ell _{1},\ell _{2},\ldots ,\ell _{M}\}$ which minimizes this cost.

Alternatively, suppose that we have a multilevel Monte Carlo implementation with a number of levels $\ell =0,1,\ldots ,L$ . Looking in particular at one level $\ell$ , is it computationally more efficient to keep that level, or would it be better to drop it and jump straight from level $\ell -1$ to $\ell +1$ ?

If we keep level $\ell$ then the contribution to the overall multilevel estimator due to samples involving level $\ell$ is

$$\begin{eqnarray}\frac{1}{N_{\ell }}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N_{\ell }}(P_{\ell }^{(n)}-P_{\ell -1}^{(n)})+\frac{1}{N_{\ell +1}}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{N_{\ell +1}}(P_{\ell +1}^{(n)}-P_{\ell }^{(n)}).\end{eqnarray}$$

The usual multilevel analysis shows that for optimality $N_{\ell }\propto \sqrt{V_{\ell }/C_{\ell }}$ , where $V_{\ell }\equiv \mathbb{V}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]$ and $C_{\ell }$ is the cost of computing a single sample of $P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}$ . Hence we have

$$\begin{eqnarray}N_{\ell }=N_{\ell +1}~\sqrt{\frac{V_{\ell }}{V_{\ell +1}}~\frac{C_{\ell +1}}{C_{\ell }}}.\end{eqnarray}$$

The combined variance from the two terms is

$$\begin{eqnarray}\frac{1}{N_{\ell }}V_{\ell }+\frac{1}{N_{\ell +1}}V_{\ell +1}=\frac{V_{\ell +1}}{N_{\ell +1}}\biggl(1+\sqrt{\frac{V_{\ell }~C_{\ell }}{V_{\ell +1}\,C_{\ell +1}}}\biggr),\end{eqnarray}$$

and the combined cost is

$$\begin{eqnarray}N_{\ell }\,C_{\ell }+N_{\ell +1}\,C_{\ell +1}=N_{\ell +1}\,C_{\ell +1}\biggl(1+\sqrt{\frac{V_{\ell }~C_{\ell }}{V_{\ell +1}\,C_{\ell +1}}}\biggr),\end{eqnarray}$$

and so the product of the combined variance and combined cost is

$$\begin{eqnarray}V_{\ell +1}\,C_{\ell +1}\biggl(1+\sqrt{\frac{V_{\ell }~C_{\ell }}{V_{\ell +1}\,C_{\ell +1}}}\biggr)^{2}.\end{eqnarray}$$

On the other hand, if we drop level $\ell$ and jump straight from level $\ell -1$ to $\ell +1$ , then the replacement estimator is

$$\begin{eqnarray}\frac{1}{\widetilde{N}_{\ell +1}}\mathop{\sum }_{n=1}^{\widetilde{N}_{\ell }}(P_{\ell +1}^{(n)}-P_{\ell -1}^{(n)}).\end{eqnarray}$$

Its variance is $\widetilde{V}_{\ell +1}/\widetilde{N}_{\ell +1}$ , where $\widetilde{V}_{\ell +1}\equiv \mathbb{V}[P_{\ell +1}-P_{\ell -1}]$ , and its cost is $\widetilde{N}_{\ell +1}\widetilde{C}_{\ell +1}$ , where $\widetilde{C}_{\ell +1}$ is the cost of a single sample of $P_{\ell +1}-P_{\ell -1}$ . Hence, the product of the variance and the cost is

$$\begin{eqnarray}\widetilde{V}_{\ell +1}~\widetilde{C}_{\ell +1}.\end{eqnarray}$$

The question now is whether

(2.5) $$\begin{eqnarray}\widetilde{V}_{\ell +1}\,\widetilde{C}_{\ell +1}<V_{\ell +1}\,C_{\ell +1}\biggl(1+\sqrt{\frac{V_{\ell }~C_{\ell }}{V_{\ell +1}\,C_{\ell +1}}}\biggr)^{2}.\end{eqnarray}$$

If this test is true, then it is best to drop level $\ell$ , because for a fixed computational cost this will deliver the lower variance, or for a fixed variance it can be achieved at a lower computational cost.

The main contribution to both $C_{\ell +1}$ and $\widetilde{C}_{\ell +1}$ comes from the level $\ell +1$ simulation which produces the output $P_{\ell +1}$ , so we will assume from here on that $\widetilde{C}_{\ell +1}\approx C_{\ell +1}$ . The cost ratio $C_{\ell }/C_{\ell +1}$ is usually known a priori, and the variance ratio $V_{\ell }/V_{\ell +1}$ is often known asymptotically as $\ell \rightarrow \infty$ , or can be estimated empirically. The key question is how $\widetilde{V}_{\ell +1}$ compares to $V_{\ell +1}$ . This could also be quantified empirically, by generating a few Monte Carlo samples for $P_{\ell +1}-P_{\ell -1}$ . Alternatively, we can perform some analysis to gain some insight into the question.

Using the standard result for the variance of a sum of two random variables, we have

$$\begin{eqnarray}\widetilde{V}_{\ell +1}=V_{\ell +1}+2{\it\rho}\sqrt{V_{\ell }~V_{\ell +1}}+V_{\ell },\end{eqnarray}$$

where ${\it\rho}$ is the correlation between $P_{\ell +1}-P_{\ell }$ and $P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}$ . We can now consider two extremes, ${\it\rho}=1$ and ${\it\rho}=0$ .

If ${\it\rho}=1$ , and so we have perfect correlation between the increments at different levels, then

$$\begin{eqnarray}\widetilde{V}_{\ell +1}=V_{\ell +1}\biggl(1+\sqrt{\frac{V_{\ell }}{V_{\ell +1}}}\biggr)^{2}.\end{eqnarray}$$

Since $C_{\ell }<C_{\ell +1}$ , it follows that the test (2.5) is never satisfied, and so it is best to retain level $\ell$ . Near-perfect correlation is likely to arise in PDE applications with finite-dimensional uncertainty in the initial data, boundary data, or PDE coefficients. In this case, the increments $P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}$ obtained in going from one level to the next come from the progressive elimination of truncation error due to the discretization of the PDE.

On the other hand, if ${\it\rho}=0$ , and so the increments at different levels are independent, then $\widetilde{V}_{\ell +1}=V_{\ell +1}+V_{\ell }$ and so we drop level $\ell$ if

$$\begin{eqnarray}1+\frac{V_{\ell }}{V_{\ell +1}}<\biggl(1+\sqrt{\frac{V_{\ell }~C_{\ell }}{V_{\ell +1}\,C_{\ell +1}}}\biggr)^{2}.\end{eqnarray}$$

2.7. MLQMC

Giles and Waterhouse (Reference Giles and Waterhouse2009) developed a variant of MLMC which uses quasi-Monte Carlo samples instead of independent Monte Carlo samples. This was based on extensible rank-1 lattices developed at UNSW (Dick, Pillichshammer and Waterhouse Reference Dick, Pillichshammer and Waterhouse2007). QMC is known to be most effective for low-dimensional applications, and the numerical results were very encouraging for SDE applications in which the dominant computational cost was on the coarsest levels of resolution. However, there was no supporting theory for this research.

More recently, there has been considerable research on the theoretical foundations for multilevel QMC (MLQMC) methods; see Niu, Hickernell, Mller-Gronbach and Ritter (Reference Niu, Hickernell, Mller-Gronbach and Ritter2010), Kuo, Schwab and Sloan (Reference Kuo, Schwab and Sloan2015), Dick et al. (Reference Dick, Kuo and Sloan2013), Baldeaux and Gnewuch (Reference Baldeaux and Gnewuch2014) and Dick and Gnewuch (Reference Dick and Gnewuch2014a , Reference Dick and Gnewuch2014b ). These theoretical developments are very encouraging, showing that under certain conditions they lead to multilevel methods with a complexity which is $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-p})$ with $p<2$ .

3. MLMC implementation

3.1. MLMC algorithm

Based on the theory in Section 2.1, the geometric MLMC algorithm used for the numerical tests in this paper is given in Algorithm 1.

In the above algorithm, the equation for the optimal $N_{\ell }$ is

(3.1) $$\begin{eqnarray}N_{\ell }=\lceil 2\,{\it\varepsilon}^{-2}\,\sqrt{V_{\ell }/C_{\ell }}~\biggl(\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}\sqrt{V_{\ell }\,C_{\ell }}\biggr)\rceil ,\end{eqnarray}$$

where $V_{\ell }$ is the estimated variance, and $C_{\ell }$ is the cost of an individual sample on level $\ell$ . This ensures that the estimated variance of the combined multilevel estimator is less than ${\it\varepsilon}^{2}/2$ .

The test for weak convergence tries to ensure that $|\mathbb{E}[P-P_{L}]|<{\it\varepsilon}/\sqrt{2}$ , to achieve an MSE which is less than ${\it\varepsilon}^{2}$ , with ${\it\varepsilon}$ being a user-specified RMS accuracy. If $\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]~\propto ~2^{-{\it\alpha}\ell }$ , then the remaining error is

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[P-P_{L}]=\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =L+1}^{\infty }\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]=\mathbb{E}[P_{L}-P_{L-1}]~/~(2^{{\it\alpha}}-1).\end{eqnarray}$$

This leads to the convergence test $|\mathbb{E}[P_{L}-P_{L-1}]|/(2^{{\it\alpha}}-1)<{\it\varepsilon}/\sqrt{2},$ but for robustness, we extend this check to extrapolate from the previous two data points $\mathbb{E}[P_{L-1}-P_{L-2}]$ , $\mathbb{E}[P_{L-2}-P_{L-3}]$ , and take the maximum over all three as the estimated remaining error.

It is important to note that this algorithm is heuristic; it is not guaranteed to achieve an MSE error which is less than ${\it\varepsilon}^{2}$ . The main MLMC theorem in Section 2.1 does provide a guarantee, but the conditions of the theorem assume a priori knowledge of the constants $c_{1}$ and $c_{2}$ governing the weak convergence and the variance convergence as $\ell \rightarrow \infty$ . These two constants are in effect being estimated in the numerical algorithm described above.

In addition, the accuracy of the variance estimate at each level depends on the size of the sample set. If it is small, then this variance estimate may be poor; we will see later that the implementation sets a minimum estimate by extrapolation from coarser levels with more samples.

3.2. Overview of MATLAB implementation

The results to be presented later all use the same two routines written in MATLAB.

 mlmc.m: driver code which performs the MLMC calculation using an application-specific routine to compute $\sum _{n}(P_{\ell }^{(n)}-P_{\ell -1}^{(n)})^{p}$ for $p=1,2$ and a specified number of independent samples.

 mlmc_test.m: a program which perform various tests and then calls mlmc.m to perform a number of MLMC calculations.

These two routines, and all of the application-specific routines, can be downloaded from Giles (Reference Giles2014).

3.3. MLMC test routine

mlmc_test.m first performs a set of calculations using a fixed number of samples on each level of resolution, and produces four plots:

 $\log _{2}(V_{\ell })$ versus level $\ell$ ,

 $\log _{2}(|\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]|)$ versus level $\ell$ ,

 consistency check versus level,

 kurtosis versus level.

The last two of these need some explanation. If $a,b,c$ are estimates for $\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell -1}^{f}]$ , $\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }^{f}]$ , $\mathbb{E}[Y_{\ell }]$ , respectively, then it should be true that $a-b+c\approx 0$ . The consistency check verifies that this is true, to within the accuracy one would expect due to Monte Carlo sampling error. This is particularly important when $P_{\ell }^{f}\neq P_{\ell }^{c}$ because one is using different approximations on the coarse and fine levels.

Since

$$\begin{eqnarray}\sqrt{\mathbb{V}[a-b+c]}\leq \sqrt{\mathbb{V}[a]}+\sqrt{\mathbb{V}[b]}+\sqrt{\mathbb{V}[c]},\end{eqnarray}$$

it computes and plots the ratio

$$\begin{eqnarray}\frac{|a-b+c|}{3(\sqrt{V_{a}}+\sqrt{V_{b}}+\sqrt{V_{c}})},\end{eqnarray}$$

where $V_{a},V_{b},V_{c}$ are empirical estimates for the variances of $a,b,c$ . The probability of this ratio being greater than unity is less than 0.3%. Hence, if it is, it indicates a likely programming error, or a mathematical error in the formulation which violates the crucial identity (2.4).

The MLMC approach needs a good estimate for $V_{\ell }=\mathbb{V}[Y_{\ell }]$ , but how many samples are needed for this? As few as 10 may be sufficient in many cases for a rough estimate, but many more are needed when there are rare outliers. When the number of samples $N$ is large, the standard deviation of the sample variance for a random variable $X$ with zero mean is approximately $\sqrt{({\it\kappa}-1)/N}~\mathbb{E}[X^{2}]$ , where the kurtosis ${\it\kappa}$ is defined as ${\it\kappa}=\mathbb{E}[X^{4}]/\mathbb{E}[X^{2}]\!)^{2}$ . Hence $O({\it\kappa})$ samples are required to obtain a reasonable estimate for the variance. As well as plotting the kurtosis ${\it\kappa}_{\ell }$ , mlmc_test.m will give a warning if ${\it\kappa}_{\ell }$ is very large, as this is an indication that the empirical variance estimate may be poor.

An extreme, but important, example is when $P$ always takes the value 0 or 1. In this case we have

$$\begin{eqnarray}X\equiv P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}=\left\{\begin{array}{@{}ll@{}}1\quad & \text{probability }p,\\ -1\quad & \text{probability }q,\\ 0\quad & \text{probability }1-p-q.\end{array}\right.\end{eqnarray}$$

If $p,q\ll 1$ , then $\mathbb{E}[X]\approx 0$ , and ${\it\kappa}\approx (p+q)^{-1}\gg 1$ . Therefore, many samples are required for a good estimate of $V_{\ell }$ ; otherwise, we may get all $X^{(n)}=0$ , which will give an estimated variance of zero. What is more, the kurtosis will become worse as $\ell \rightarrow \infty$ since $p,q\rightarrow 0$ due to weak convergence.

After performing these initial tests, mlmc_test.m then uses the driver routine mlmc.m to perform the MLMC computation for a number of values of ${\it\varepsilon}$ , and plots the results. These plots will be explained later when the first results are presented.

3.4. MLMC driver routine

The first part of the documentation section at the top of mlmc.m is fairly self-explanatory.

The user must supply an application-specific function to perform the calculations to compute $Y_{\ell }$ on level $\ell$ . This function has to conform to the following template.

The first part of the code initializes various parameters, and then uses the application-specific routine mlmc_l to generate the initial N0 samples on each of the first three levels.

The next part computes (or in later passes updates) the estimates for $m_{\ell }\equiv |\mathbb{E}[Y_{\ell }]|$ , and $V_{\ell }\equiv \mathbb{V}[Y_{\ell }]$ . If the mean and variance are decaying as expected, one would expect $m_{\ell }=2^{-{\it\alpha}}\,m_{\ell -1},~V_{\ell }=2^{-{\it\beta}}\,V_{\ell -1}$ . To avoid possible problems from high kurtosis generating poor empirical estimates, the estimates for $m_{\ell }$ and $V_{\ell }$ are not allowed to decrease by more than factor $1/2$ relative to this anticipated value.Footnote 2

If the user has not supplied the values for ${\it\alpha}$ and/or ${\it\beta}$ , they are now estimated by linear regression.

Next, the optimal number of samples on each level is computed, which in turn gives the number of additional samples which will need to be generated in the next pass.

In the final part of the loop, we test for weak convergence, using the algorithm described in Section 3.1. If a new level is added, its variance is estimated by extrapolation, and the optimal number of samples is updated.

The final step after the completion of the main loop is to compute the combined multilevel estimator.

3.5. MLQMC algorithm

We conclude this chapter with the description of an MLQMC algorithm which is based on that developed by Giles and Waterhouse (Reference Giles and Waterhouse2009), but updated to bring it more in line with the MLMC algorithm in Section 3.1.

The key change in MLQMC is that $N_{\ell }$ is now the size of a set of QMC points used on level $\ell$ . This set of points is not constructed randomly and independently but instead constructed very carefully, using well-established QMC techniques such as rank-1 lattices (Dick et al. Reference Dick, Pillichshammer and Waterhouse2007) or Sobol sequences (Joe and Kuo Reference Joe and Kuo2008) to provide a relatively uniform coverage of a unit hypercube integration region. In the best cases, this results in the approximate numerical integration error being $O(N_{\ell }^{-1})$ rather than the usual $O(N_{\ell }^{-1/2})$ error which comes from Monte Carlo sampling.

Using just one set of $N_{\ell }$ points gives good accuracy, but no confidence interval. To regain a confidence interval one uses randomized QMC in which the set of points is gives a random shift (for rank-1 lattice rules) or a digital scrambling (for Sobol sequences). Using 32 sets of points, each collectively randomized, yields 32 set averages for the quantity of interest, $Y_{\ell }$ , and from these 32 random independent values the variance of their average, $V_{\ell }$ , can be estimated in the usual way.

Since $V_{\ell }$ is now defined to be the variance of the average, for a given number of levels $L$ , the aim is to choose the $N_{\ell }$ in a way which ensures that

(3.2) $$\begin{eqnarray}\mathop{\sum }_{\ell =0}^{L}V_{\ell }\leq {\it\varepsilon}^{2}/2.\end{eqnarray}$$

How can this be achieved most efficiently? Many QMC methods work naturally with $N_{\ell }$ as a power of 2. Doubling $N_{\ell }$ will usually eliminate a large fraction of the variance, so the greatest reduction in total variance relative to the additional computational effort is achieved by doubling $N_{\ell }$ on the level $\ell ^{\ast }$ given by

(3.3) $$\begin{eqnarray}\ell ^{\ast }=\arg \min _{\ell }\frac{V_{\ell }}{N_{\ell }\,C_{\ell }}.\end{eqnarray}$$

Based on this, and using the same test for weak convergence as in the MLMC algorithm, the MLQMC algorithm is given in Algorithm 2.

4. Introduction to applications

The remainder of the article presents and discusses a large number of different applications using MLMC methods. In part, the large number is to illustrate the flexibility and generality of the approach, and stimulate ideas on how it could be used for other applications which the reader may be interested in, but the variety of applications is also chosen to illustrate different responses to the following questions.

(1) How are the levels defined?

This is often quite simple, but in some cases, for example when using adaptive time-stepping, it is not so obvious.

(2) How are the coarse and fine samples coupled when computing the difference $P_{\ell }({\it\omega})-P_{\ell -1}({\it\omega})$ ?

What does it even mean for $P_{\ell }({\it\omega})$ and $P_{\ell -1}({\it\omega})$ to correspond to the same sample ${\it\omega}$ ? In some cases, it is very simple, but in other cases, such as for the continuous-time Markov chains, it requires a key insight to construct a suitable coupling.

(3) Are there problems with discontinuous outputs?

When the output function is a discontinuous function of the intermediate solution $U$ , there is the possibility that a small difference between the intermediate solutions for the coarse and fine samples leads to an $O(1)$ value for $P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}$ . This usually leads to a larger variance, and hence a lower value for ${\it\beta}$ . Addressing this problem is a critical issue, and we will consider a variety of different techniques. Many of these exploit the flexibility of slightly different approximations for the coarse and fine samples, provided always that the identity (2.4) is respected, so that the telescoping sum is still valid.

(4) Is there scope for constructing even more efficient multilevel estimators?

As with the techniques for handling discontinuous output functions, there can be ways of exploiting the flexibility of different coarse and fine approximations to achieve a higher rate of variance convergence than one would otherwise expect due to the rate of strong convergence of the intermediate solution.

(5) What is the current status on supporting numerical analysis to explain the observed behaviour of numerical algorithms?

For many applications this is the greatest challenge, but great progress has been made in the past five years.

5. SDEs

5.1. EulerMaruyama discretization

The original multilevel path simulation paper (Giles Reference Giles2008b ) treated stochastic differential equations

$$\begin{eqnarray}\text{d}S_{t}=a(S_{t},t)~\text{d}t+b(S_{t},t)~\text{d}W_{t},\end{eqnarray}$$

using the simple EulerMaruyama discretization with a uniform time-step $h$ and Brownian increments ${\rm\Delta}W_{n}$ ,

$$\begin{eqnarray}\widehat{S}_{n+1}=\widehat{S}_{n}+a(\widehat{S}_{n},t_{n})\,h+b(\widehat{S}_{n},t_{n})\,{\rm\Delta}W_{n}.\end{eqnarray}$$

The multilevel Monte Carlo implementation is very simple. On level $\ell$ , the uniform time-step is taken to be $h_{\ell }=h_{0}\,M^{\ell }$ , for some integer $M$ . The time-step $h_{0}$ on the coarsest level is often taken to be the interval length $T$ , so that there is just one time-step for the entire interval, but this is not required, and in some applications using such a large time-step may lead to numerical results which are so inaccurate that they are not helpful, that is, they are such a poor control variate for the finer approximations that they do not lead to a reduction in the variance. In such cases, it would be better to start with a smaller value for $h_{0}$ .

The multilevel coupling is achieved by using the same underlying driving Brownian path for the coarse and fine paths; this is accomplished by summing the Brownian increments for the fine path time-steps to obtain the Brownian increments for the coarse time-steps. The multilevel estimator is then the natural one defined in (2.2), with the specific payoff approximation $P_{\ell }$ depending on the particular application.

Provided the SDE satisfies the usual conditions (see Theorem 10.2.2 in Kloeden and Platen Reference Kloeden and Platen1992), the strong error for the Euler discretization with time-step $h$ is $O(h^{1/2})$ , so that

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{E}[\Vert S-\widehat{S}\Vert ^{2}]=O(h).\end{eqnarray}$$

For Lipschitz payoff functions $P$ (such as European, Asian and lookback options in finance) for which

$$\begin{eqnarray}|P(S_{1})-P(S_{2})|\leq K\Vert S_{1}-S_{2}\Vert ,\end{eqnarray}$$

we have

$$\begin{eqnarray}\mathbb{V}[P-P_{\ell }]\leq \mathbb{E}[(P-P_{\ell })^{2}]\leq K^{2}~\mathbb{E}[\Vert S-\widehat{S}_{\ell }\Vert ^{2}],\end{eqnarray}$$

and

$$\begin{eqnarray}V_{\ell }\equiv \mathbb{V}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]\leq 2(\mathbb{V}[P-P_{\ell }]+\mathbb{V}[P-P_{\ell -1}]),\end{eqnarray}$$

and hence $V_{\ell }=O(h_{\ell })$ .

If $h_{\ell }=4^{-\ell }h_{0}$ , as in the numerical examples in Giles (Reference Giles2008b ), then this gives ${\it\alpha}=2$ , ${\it\beta}=4$ and ${\it\gamma}=2$ . Alternatively, if $h_{\ell }=2^{-\ell }h_{0}$ with twice as many time-steps on each successive level, as used in the numerical examples in this article, then ${\it\alpha}=1$ , ${\it\beta}=2$ and ${\it\gamma}=1$ . In either case, Theorem 2.1 gives the complexity to achieve an RMS error of ${\it\varepsilon}$ to be $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-2}(\log {\it\varepsilon})^{2})$ , which is near-optimal, because Creutzig, Dereich, Mller-Gronbach and Ritter (Reference Creutzig, Dereich, Mller-Gronbach and Ritter2009) prove an $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-2})$ lower bound for the complexity. The same paper also proves that MLMC achieves an $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-2}(\log {\it\varepsilon})^{2})$ worst-case optimal complexity for a class of Lipschitz path-dependent functions.

Figure 5.1 shows results for a financial call option with a single underlying asset satisfying the geometric Brownian motion SDE,

$$\begin{eqnarray}\text{d}S_{t}=r\,S_{t}~\text{d}t+{\it\sigma}\,S_{t}~\text{d}W_{t},\end{eqnarray}$$

and payoff $P(S)\equiv \exp (-rT)\,\max (S_{T}-K,0)$ with $r=0.05,{\it\sigma}=0.2,T=1,S_{0}=100,K=100$ . The full code is provided in Giles (Reference Giles2014).

Plots (a) and (b) show the variance and absolute mean value for both $P_{\ell }$ and $P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}$ . These are based on an initial sample of $10^{5}$ paths. The line for $\log _{2}\mathbb{V}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]$ in plot (a) has a slope of approximately $-1$ , corresponding to a variance proportional to $h_{\ell }$ , as expected. The line for $\log _{2}|\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}]|$ also has a slope of approximately $-1$ , implying an $O(h_{\ell })$ weak convergence.

Plots (c) and (d) show the consistency check and kurtosis, as discussed in Section 3.3. These indicate that there is no problem with the consistency, and the kurtosis is actually improving slightly with level.

Plots (e) and (f) have the results from five separate MLMC calculations, each with a different specified accuracy ${\it\varepsilon}$ to be achieved. Plot (e) shows the number of samples which is used for each level of the MLMC computation. The number of levels increases as ${\it\varepsilon}$ decreases, as described in Section 3.1, to achieve the required weak error. The number of samples also varies with level, with many more on the coarsest level with just one time-step. On the finer levels, the optimal allocation of computational effort leads to $N_{\ell }\propto \sqrt{V_{\ell }/C_{\ell }}\approx 2^{-\ell }$ .

Plot (f) displays the total computational cost $C$ , multiplied by ${\it\varepsilon}^{2}$ . If $C$ were approximately proportional to ${\it\varepsilon}^{-2}$ then ${\it\varepsilon}^{2}\,C$ would be approximately constant. Indeed, this is what is seen, with the slight increase as ${\it\varepsilon}$ decreases being due to the $|\!\log {\it\varepsilon}|^{2}$ term in Theorem 2.1. For comparison, plot (f) also displays the cost using the standard Monte Carlo algorithm on the finest level used by the MLMC algorithm. The cost ratio is between 5 and 12, illustrating the benefits provided by the MLMC algorithm.

Figure 5.2 illustrates the problem with discontinuous payoff functions. The underlying SDE is exactly the same, but the payoff is a digital option with payoff $P(S)\equiv 10\,\exp (-rT)\,H(S_{T}-K)$ , where $H(x)$ is the Heaviside step function. On the finer levels, most samples have fine and coarse paths which end on the same side of the strike $K$ , and hence give $P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}=0$ . However, noting that the strong error is $O(h_{\ell }^{1/2})$ , and there is a bounded density of paths terminating in the neighbourhood of $K$ , there is therefore an $O(h_{\ell }^{1/2})$ fraction of the samples with the coarse and fine paths on either side of the strike, with $P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}=\pm 1$ . This gives $V_{\ell }=O(h^{1/2})$ , and this lower rate of convergence is clearly visible in plot (a). Furthermore, $\mathbb{E}[(P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1})^{4}]=O(h_{\ell }^{1/2})$ and so the kurtosis is $O(h_{\ell }^{-1/2})$ ; this increase in kurtosis is obvious in plot (d), which illustrates why this is a helpful quantity to plot. Consequently, this application has ${\it\alpha}=1$ , ${\it\beta}=1/2$ , ${\it\gamma}=1$ , leading to the MLMC complexity being $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-2.5})$ . This slightly worse complexity is visible in plot (f), and the computational savings compared to the standard Monte Carlo method are lower.

Table 5.1 summarizes the observed variance convergence rate in numerical experiments for a number of different financial options; the Asian option is based on the average value of the underlying asset, the lookback is based on its maximum or minimum value, and the barrier is a discontinuous function of the maximum or minimum. The table also displays the theoretical results which have been obtained; the digital option analysis is due to Avikainen (Reference Avikainen2009) while the others are due to Giles, Higham and Mao (Reference Giles, Higham and Mao2009).

5.2. Milstein discretization

For Lipschitz payoffs, the variance $V_{\ell }$ for the natural multilevel estimator converges at twice the order of the strong convergence of the numerical approximation of the SDE. This immediately suggests that it would be better to replace the EulerMaruyama discretization by the Milstein discretization (Giles Reference Giles, Keller, Heinrich and Niederreiter2008a ) since it gives first-order strong convergence under certain conditions (see Theorem 10.3.5 in Kloeden and Platen Reference Kloeden and Platen1992).

For a scalar SDE the Milstein discretization is

$$\begin{eqnarray}\widehat{S}_{n+1}=\widehat{S}_{n}+a(\widehat{S}_{n},t_{n})\,h+b(\widehat{S}_{n},t_{n})\,{\rm\Delta}W_{n}+{\textstyle \frac{1}{2}}b(\widehat{S}_{n},t_{n})\frac{\partial b}{\partial S}(\widehat{S}_{n},t_{n})({\rm\Delta}W_{n}^{2}-h)\end{eqnarray}$$

and Figure 5.3 demonstrates the improved results obtained for the call option based on a single underlying GBM asset. $V_{\ell }$ is now $O(h_{\ell }^{2})$ , leading to ${\it\alpha}=1$ , ${\it\beta}=2$ , ${\it\gamma}=1$ , and there is a significant reduction in the total computational cost compared to MLMC using the EulerMaruyama discretization.

Because ${\it\beta}>{\it\gamma}$ , the dominant computational cost is on the coarsest levels. Since these are low-dimensional, they are well suited to the use of quasi-Monte Carlo methods which are particularly effective in lower dimensions. This has been investigated by Giles and Waterhouse (Reference Giles and Waterhouse2009) using a rank-1 lattice rule to generate the quasi-random numbers, randomization with 32 independent offsets to obtain confidence intervals, and a standard Brownian bridge construction of the increments of the driving Brownian process. The numerical results showed that MLMC on its own was better than QMC on its own, but the combination of the two was even better. The QMC treatment greatly reduced the variance per sample for the coarsest levels, resulting in significantly reduced costs overall. In the simplest case of a Lipschitz European payoff, the computational complexity was reduced from $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-2})$ to approximately $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-1.5})$ .

Digital options

As with the EulerMaruyama discretization, discontinuous payoffs pose a challenge to the multilevel Monte Carlo approach because small differences in the coarse and fine path simulations can lead to an $O(1)$ difference in the payoff function. In the case of a digital option, if we use the natural multilevel estimator then $P_{\ell }-P_{\ell -1}=O(1)$ for an $O(h_{\ell })$ fraction of the paths, giving $V_{\ell }=O(h_{\ell })$ , and a kurtosis which is $O(h_{\ell }^{-1})$ . To obtain a multilevel estimator with an improved variance convergence, we exploit the ideas of Section 2.1 and develop different estimators $P^{c}$ and $P^{f}$ for the coarse and fine paths, based on one of the following ideas:

 conditional expectation,

 splitting,

 change of measure.

The conditional expectation approach builds on a well-established technique for payoff smoothing which is used for pathwise sensitivity analysis (see, for example, pp. 399400 in Glasserman Reference Glasserman2004). We start by considering the fine path simulation, and make a slight change by using the EulerMaruyama discretization for the final time-step, instead of the Milstein discretization. Conditional on the value $\widehat{S}_{N-1}$ which is the numerical approximation of $S_{T-h}$ one time-step before the maturity $T$ , the numerical approximation for the final value $\widehat{S}_{N}$ has a Gaussian distribution, and for a simple digital option the conditional expectation is known analytically. Thus the fine path payoff can be taken to be

$$\begin{eqnarray}P_{\ell }^{f}=\exp (-rT)\,{\rm\Phi}\biggl(\frac{\widehat{S}_{N-1}^{f}+a(\widehat{S}_{N-1}^{f})h_{\ell }-K}{b(\widehat{S}_{N-1}^{f})\sqrt{h_{\ell }}}\biggr),\end{eqnarray}$$

where ${\rm\Phi}$ is the normal cumulative distribution function.

A similar treatment is used for the coarse path, except that in the final time-step, we re-use the known value of the Brownian increment for the second-last fine time-step, which corresponds to the first half of the final coarse time-step. This results in the conditional distribution for the coarse path underlying at maturity matching that of the fine path to within $O(h)$ , for both the mean and the standard deviation (Giles, Debrabant and Rler Reference Giles, Debrabant and Rler2013), and the corresponding coarse path payoff function is

$$\begin{eqnarray}P_{\ell -1}^{c}=\exp (-rT)\,{\rm\Phi}\biggl(\frac{\widehat{S}_{N-2}^{c}+a(\widehat{S}_{N-2}^{c})h_{\ell -1}+b(\widehat{S}_{N-2}^{c})\sqrt{h_{\ell }}-K}{b(\widehat{S}_{N-2}^{c})\sqrt{h_{\ell }}}\biggr).\end{eqnarray}$$

Consequently, the difference in payoff between the coarse and fine paths near the payoff discontinuity is $O(h^{1/2})$ , giving a variance which is approximately $O(h^{3/2})$ , and a kurtosis which is approximately $O(h^{-1/2})$ . This leads to ${\it\alpha}=1$ , ${\it\beta}=3/2$ and ${\it\gamma}=1$ . Since ${\it\beta}>{\it\gamma}$ , the MLMC complexity is $O({\it\varepsilon}^{-2})$ .

This is all illustrated by the numerical results in Figure 5.4. One particularly interesting feature of these results is that there is zero variance on the coarsest level. This is because there is only one time-step on the coarsest level, and therefore the conditional expectation is taken immediately and every sample gives the same payoff.

It is very important in this conditional expectation formulation that $\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell -1}^{c}]=\mathbb{E}[P_{\ell -1}^{f}]$ so that the numerical payoff approximation on level $\ell -1$ has the same expected value regardless of whether it is the coarser or finer of the two levels. This ensures that the identity in equation (2.4) is respected so that the telescoping summation remains valid.

The conditional expectation technique works well in one dimension, where there is a known analytic value for the conditional expectation, but in multiple dimensions it may not be known. In this case, one can use the technique of splitting (Asmussen and Glynn Reference Asmussen and Glynn2007). Here the conditional expectation is replaced by a numerical estimate, averaging over a number of sub-samples. That is, for each set of Brownian increments up to one fine time-step before the end, we use a number of samples of the final Brownian increment to produce an average payoff. If the number of sub-samples is chosen appropriately, the variance is the same, to leading order, without any increase in the computational cost, again to leading order. Because of its simplicity and generality, this is now the authors preferred approach. Furthermore, one can revert to using the Milstein approximation for the final time-step.

The change of measure approach is another approximation to the conditional expectation. Using the EulerMaruyama approximation for the final time-step, the fine and coarse path conditional distributions at maturity are two very similar Gaussian distributions. Instead of following the splitting approach of taking corresponding samples from these two distributions, we can take a sample from a third Gaussian distribution (with a mean and variance perhaps equal to the average of the other two). This leads to the introduction of a RadonNikodym derivative for each path, and the difference in the payoffs from the two paths is then due to the difference in their RadonNikodym derivatives.

In the specific context of digital options, this is a more complicated method to implement, and the resulting variance is no better. However, in other contexts a similar approach can be very effective.

Lookback and barrier options

Lookback and barrier options are financial options which depend on the minimum (or maximum) values of the underlying asset during the whole simulation interval $[0,T]$ . A multilevel estimator based directly on the minimum (or maximum) of the values at the discrete time-steps will have a poor variance. This is because there is an $O(h^{1/2})$ variation in the asset value within each time-step of size $h$ , and therefore there is an $O(h_{\ell })$ difference on average between the minimum (or maximum) values for the coarse and fine paths. This results in an $O(h_{\ell })$ variance for lookback options which are a Lipschitz function of the minimum (or maximum), and an even worse $O(h_{\ell }^{1/2})$ variance for barrier options which are a discontinuous function of the minimum (or maximum).

The key to achieving an improved variance is the definition of a Brownian bridge interpolant based on the approximation that the drift and volatility do not vary within the time-step (Giles Reference Giles, Keller, Heinrich and Niederreiter2008a ).
